courseLearningOutcomes.description: Community Dynamics: Evaluate through case studies and theoretical frameworks how communities form, sustain, transform, and dissolve while creating both belonging and exclusion
Community Engaged Scholarship Frameworks: Understand and critique participatory research methods, examining how different approaches position community members as subjects versus co-investigators
Asset and Deficit Approaches: Analyze how different frameworks identify community strengths versus problems, understanding the implications of each approach
Power and Positionality: Critically analyze power dynamics, contested boundaries, and issues of social positioning within community contexts through case studies
Community Knowledge Systems: Evaluate different epistemologies and forms of knowledge production within and about communities
Community Theories: Apply multiple theoretical lenses to understand communities across scales and contexts

programLearningOutcomes.description: Community-Engaged Learning and Social Responsibility - Students will acquire the skills and experience to effectively analyze and contribute to community-based endeavors through holistic, socially responsible actions and interpretations

Applied Interdisciplinary Skills in the Liberal Arts - Students will integrate interdisciplinary knowledge and methods from the liberal arts to engage with complex, community challenges in multiple contexts and scales

Ethical Decision-Making and Critical Reflection - Students will apply ethical decision-making frameworks to analyze and navigate power dynamics within communities, fostering equitable and just outcomes

majorAssessments.name: Community Quest - Comparative Community Analysis Paper
